<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/18/lead-election-social-media-story?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Making Sense of the Social Media Hooplah
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Will Ferrell saying "I get it"" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=285 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3owzWl78kny9s2GOvC/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt='Will Ferrell saying "I get it"' style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3owzWl78kny9s2GOvC/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not since the “relationship status” button was added to Facebook has there been this much intense focus on social media sites. Yesterday, Twitter kept the issue of curtailing misinformation top of mind by <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/17/politics/scott-atlas-face-masks-coronavirus/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">taking down</a> a tweet from Scott Atlas, one of President Trump’s top coronavirus task force members.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Atlas's tweet questioned the efficacy of wearing a mask, reading “Masks work? NO." </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Get caught up </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Social media companies have danced, tip-toed, and flip-flopped on the contentious issue of content moderation in the past week. Here were the biggest developments:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Wednesday:</strong></span><span> Twitter </span><span><a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/twitter-blocking-nypost-china-hunter-biden-account-locked-1234808416/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">locked the NY Post’s account</a></span><span> and blocked users from sharing an article the Post wrote about Joe Biden’s son, Hunter. The company said the article contained hacked materials; Facebook also took steps to limit the distribution of the article because it could potentially contain misinformation. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Thursday:</strong></span><span> Twitter doubled down and temporarily locked the official Trump campaign account for trying to share the Post article. YouTube also announced </span><span><a href="https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/harmful-conspiracy-theories-youtube/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new policies</a></span><span> designed to limit the sharing of “conspiracy theory content used to justify real-world violence”—primarily aimed at the QAnon conspiracy theory. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Friday:</strong></span><span> In its best Tony Hawk impression, Twitter pulled a 180 on the NY Post article, allowing users to share it and </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/twitter-hacked-materials-rules-censorship-fd3ec0da-7e06-4c5b-a5f5-331ad1c5320c.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">changing the policies</a></span><span> it used to block the article. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The rule at the center of it all </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The controversial law that grants social media platforms sweeping protection from user-generated content is in the spotlight again after Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas said last week that the court should <a href="https://www.axios.com/clarence-thomas-wants-to-reel-in-section-230-fad81180-1f50-48a6-b638-f9386221f4f2.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">look for the right case</a> to begin scaling it back. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While there's bipartisan support for reform, the differing motives behind each party’s distaste for Section 230—Republicans claim the law allows these platforms to exhibit anti-conservative bias, while Democrats say it doesn’t do enough to limit hate-speech—make it unlikely any legislation will be passed before the election.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> With Election Day just over two weeks away, the role of social media in America’s democratic process has become one of the defining issues of the campaign. </p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
QUOTES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/18/top-quotes-weekend?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Weekend Soundbites
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">“<strong style="color:#000">I can’t believe how fast the second wave has hit...another recession is absolutely possible.</strong>”—Katharina Utermöhl, a senior economist at Allianz, warned the FT of further economic pain as Covid-19 cases <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/700355e2-362c-4f9f-a24e-ddc9f6ea9cb0?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">continue to rise</a> across Europe.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“Additional differences...must be addressed in a comprehensive manner in the next 48 hours.”</strong>—A top aide to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced a <a href="https://www.axios.com/pelosi-deadline-white-house-stimulus-ba295a0c-011c-477c-a76f-0fdb73dbe563.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">two-day deadline</a> for any stimulus agreement before the election (the deadline is today). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“Maybe I’ll have to leave the country.”</strong>—President Trump pondered his future plans if he lost to Joe Biden during a campaign rally in Georgia.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">"Elections aren't always great at bringing people together."</strong>—New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern stated the obvious after her Labour Party <a href="https://www.npr.org/2020/10/17/924934728/new-zealand-pm-ardern-wins-re-election-in-best-showing-for-labour-party-in-decad?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dominated</a> the country’s general election. Arden has earned international praise for her handling of the coronavirus.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">“Have you seen </strong><strong style="color:#000"><em>Nurse Ratched</em></strong><strong style="color:#000">?”</strong>—Your coworker trying to make small talk this morning. Netflix tweeted that <a href="https://twitter.com/netflix/status/1317125663631892481?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">48 million people</a> have watched the show in the first 28 days of its release, making it Netflix’s most popular original Season 1 of the year.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/18/ski-mountains-gear-new-season-pandemic?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Ski Season Plows Ahead—But in Pizza Position
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="skiing" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/JrGH6KjBHJk38Y4nwm/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="skiing" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/JrGH6KjBHJk38Y4nwm/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As ski mountain resorts <a href="https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-pandemics-colorado-canada-united-states-c72af88e6879237fdb118ad033a65f7e?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">gear up</a> to reopen for the winter, we’re learning more about their plans to allow safe gnar shredding during a pandemic. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">In many ways, skiing is Covid-friendly</strong>. Masked-up skiers were defogging glasses before it was cool, and the sport already takes place outside with lots of protections against the elements. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But resorts are still taking <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/ski-resorts-open-covid-11601556076?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">major precautions</a>. Expect social distancing requirements while waiting in lines, fewer opportunities to make a new friend on a chair lift, and a toned-down après-ski scene after you get off the mountain. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Plus, less availability. With rules limiting capacity, industry giant Vail is giving first-priority to pass holders at its 34 North American locations.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On that note, good luck finding a place to stay. The real estate market in ski towns was <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/home-sales-surge-in-resort-towns-covid-11601556684?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">crazy busy</a> this summer as city dwellers looked for homes closer to nature.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The start of the ski season shows just how long we’ve been living with the pandemic. Mountains were forced to shut down when the virus first began to spread widely in March.</p>

<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There are a <em>lot</em> of people who work hard to craft this here newsletter and get it to your inbox every morning. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We like to think it’s because we’re newsletter wizards, but to tell you the truth, we owe much of this sorcery to <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N32602.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24449302.282754892;dc_trk_aid=476753350;dc_trk_cid=137781263;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;gdpr=%24{GDPR};gdpr_consent=%24{GDPR_CONSENT_755}" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Slack</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Slack is the new way of working, effectively replacing email so we can, ehrm, write this email newsletter <strong style="color:#000">faster, more organized, and more securely</strong>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N32602.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24449302.282754892;dc_trk_aid=476753350;dc_trk_cid=137781263;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;gdpr=%24{GDPR};gdpr_consent=%24{GDPR_CONSENT_755}" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Slack</a> doesn’t just help us hone our humor in team channels and test puns we’re too embarrassed to share here, their platform actually empowers us to <strong style="color:#000">catch up on projects, share data and documents, and present memes</strong> <strong style="color:#000">to our Executive Meme Committee before publication</strong>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You must understand, we’re a super serious media company and there’s a lot at stake, so we rely heavily on <a href="https://ad.doubleclick.net/ddm/trackclk/N32602.3407870MORNINGBREW/B24449302.282754892;dc_trk_aid=476753350;dc_trk_cid=137781263;dc_lat=;dc_rdid=;tag_for_child_directed_treatment=;tfua=;gdpr=%24{GDPR};gdpr_consent=%24{GDPR_CONSENT_755}" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Slack</a> to keep us connected and ensure the lights at the newsletter factory stay on.</p>

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HISTORY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/18/marking-anniversary-black-monday-wall-street?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Let's Try to Avoid This Today
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Black Monday picture" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yODE3L2JsYWNrX21vbmRheV9waWN0dXJlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Antonin Cermak/Fairfax Media via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today marks the anniversary of one of the most infamous days in Wall Street history. On October 19, 1987, the Dow Jones Industrial Average <a href="https://www.federalreservehistory.org/essays/stock_market_crash_of_1987?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dropped 22.6%</a>, the biggest single-session drop in history. It’s called...drumroll please...Black Monday. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What happened? </strong>The Brew’s Alex Hickey <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/inside-black-monday-markets-worst-oneday-drop-history?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">walks us through</a> the timeline: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Dow gained 44% in seven months by late August, stoking fears of a bubble.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Then, a “perfect storm” of conditions, including a falling dollar and the recent introduction of computerized trading, accelerated a global selloff. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>On Black Monday, risk arbitrage traders, individual investors, and portfolio insurance holders sold stocks like Girl Scout cookies.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Unlike other financial crises, Black Monday didn’t trigger a recession or a banking collapse. The Dow clawed back 57% of Black Monday losses in two sessions. And by September 1989, stocks were at pre-Black Monday levels. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The legacy of Black Monday: </strong>Among other market reforms, the U.S. installed circuit breakers that pause trading if stocks fall too much too quickly. If you remember this past March, those circuit breakers were triggered three times in just over a week when the market plummeted at the onset of the pandemic.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Start Talking
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Every Monday, we curate a handful of balanced resources about a hot-button business issue and encourage you to discuss with friends, family, or coworkers.</em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week’s topic: </strong>Diversity training. Late last month, President Trump issued an executive order laying new ground rules for diversity and inclusion training at companies with federal contracts or grants. It’s been...controversial. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>First, catch up on what’s been going on and what both sides are arguing about. (</span><span><a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/10/09/trump-rescind-diversity-racism-executive-order/5939538002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">USA Today</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Find basic information about Trump’s order, including why it prohibits unconscious bias training. (</span><span><a href="https://www.dol.gov/agencies/ofccp/faqs/executive-order-13950?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Department of Labor</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Read the letter from a coalition of 150+ business groups that say the order is </span><span><a href="http://image.uschamber.com/lib/fe3911727164047d731673/m/5/b5c62775-5376-4f8d-9384-35b76ce39682.pdf?utm_medium=Email&utm_source=SFMC&utm_campaign=&utm_content=&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">already having</a></span><span> a “broadly chilling effect.”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>What is critical race theory, the prominent framework for examining racism that’s under fire by the Trump administration? (</span><span><a href="https://time.com/5891138/critical-race-theory-explained/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Time</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Corporate America’s diversity training programs have never been perfect. (</span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/corporate-america-racism-diversity-training-d5fe4180-2c2f-41ed-a846-8aad11970d42.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Axios</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nMaking Sense of the Social Media Hooplah\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Will Ferrell saying \"I get it\"\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=285 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/3owzWl78kny9s2GOvC/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt='Will Ferrell saying \"I get it\"' style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/3owzWl78kny9s2GOvC/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot since the “relationship status” button was added to Facebook has there been this much intense focus on social media sites. Yesterday, Twitter kept the issue of curtailing misinformation top of mind by \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/17/politics/scott-atlas-face-masks-coronavirus/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etaking down\u003c/a\u003e a tweet from Scott Atlas, one of President Trump’s top coronavirus task force members.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAtlas's tweet questioned the efficacy of wearing a mask, reading “Masks work? NO.\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eGet caught up \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSocial media companies have danced, tip-toed, and flip-flopped on the contentious issue of content moderation in the past week. Here were the biggest developments:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWednesday:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Twitter \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/twitter-blocking-nypost-china-hunter-biden-account-locked-1234808416/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elocked the NY Post’s account\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e and blocked users from sharing an article the Post wrote about Joe Biden’s son, Hunter. The company said the article contained hacked materials; Facebook also took steps to limit the distribution of the article because it could potentially contain misinformation. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThursday:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Twitter doubled down and temporarily locked the official Trump campaign account for trying to share the Post article. YouTube also announced \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/harmful-conspiracy-theories-youtube/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew policies\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e designed to limit the sharing of “conspiracy theory content used to justify real-world violence”—primarily aimed at the QAnon conspiracy theory. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFriday:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e In its best Tony Hawk impression, Twitter pulled a 180 on the NY Post article, allowing users to share it and \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/twitter-hacked-materials-rules-censorship-fd3ec0da-7e06-4c5b-a5f5-331ad1c5320c.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echanging the policies\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e it used to block the article. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe rule at the center of it all \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSection 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The controversial law that grants social media platforms sweeping protection from user-generated content is in the spotlight again after Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas said last week that the court should \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/clarence-thomas-wants-to-reel-in-section-230-fad81180-1f50-48a6-b638-f9386221f4f2.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elook for the right case\u003c/a\u003e to begin scaling it back. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile there's bipartisan support for reform, the differing motives behind each party’s distaste for Section 230—Republicans claim the law allows these platforms to exhibit anti-conservative bias, while Democrats say it doesn’t do enough to limit hate-speech—make it unlikely any legislation will be passed before the election.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e With Election Day just over two weeks away, the role of social media in America’s democratic process has become one of the defining issues of the campaign. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs ski mountain resorts \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-pandemics-colorado-canada-united-states-c72af88e6879237fdb118ad033a65f7e?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egear up\u003c/a\u003e to reopen for the winter, we’re learning more about their plans to allow safe gnar shredding during a pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIn many ways, skiing is Covid-friendly\u003c/strong\u003e. Masked-up skiers were defogging glasses before it was cool, and the sport already takes place outside with lots of protections against the elements. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut resorts are still taking \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/ski-resorts-open-covid-11601556076?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emajor precautions\u003c/a\u003e. Expect social distancing requirements while waiting in lines, fewer opportunities to make a new friend on a chair lift, and a toned-down après-ski scene after you get off the mountain. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePlus, less availability. With rules limiting capacity, industry giant Vail is giving first-priority to pass holders at its 34 North American locations.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn that note, good luck finding a place to stay. The real estate market in ski towns was \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/home-sales-surge-in-resort-towns-covid-11601556684?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecrazy busy\u003c/a\u003e this summer as city dwellers looked for homes closer to nature.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe start of the ski season shows just how long we’ve been living with the pandemic. Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eToday marks the anniversary of one of the most infamous days in Wall Street history. On October 19, 1987, the Dow Jones Industrial Average \u003ca href=\"https://www.federalreservehistory.org/essays/stock_market_crash_of_1987?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edropped 22.6%\u003c/a\u003e, the biggest single-session drop in history. It’s called...drumroll please...Black Monday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat happened? \u003c/strong\u003eThe Brew’s Alex Hickey \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/inside-black-monday-markets-worst-oneday-drop-history?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewalks us through\u003c/a\u003e the timeline: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Dow gained 44% in seven months by late August, stoking fears of a bubble.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThen, a “perfect storm” of conditions, including a falling dollar and the recent introduction of computerized trading, accelerated a global selloff. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOn Black Monday, risk arbitrage traders, individual investors, and portfolio insurance holders sold stocks like Girl Scout cookies.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUnlike other financial crises, Black Monday didn’t trigger a recession or a banking collapse. The Dow clawed back 57% of Black Monday losses in two sessions. And by September 1989, stocks were at pre-Black Monday levels. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe legacy of Black Monday: \u003c/strong\u003eAmong other market reforms, the U.S. installed circuit breakers that pause trading if stocks fall too much too quickly. If you remember this past March, those circuit breakers were triggered three times in just over a week when the market plummeted at the onset of the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
